titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nina B. de Fels Collection MC.350
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-12-12 19:10:04 -0500.

did.abstract: Nina B. de Fels (née Bauman) is a high school teacher in New York City. She attended New York University's University Heights campus as an undergraduate from 1968-1970. The Nina B. de Fels Collection (dated 1967-1972) consists of materials created and collected by de Fels documenting her experiences as an undergraduate student at NYU's University Heights campus in the Bronx. The collection includes personal documents, including de Fels' transcript, acceptance letter, transcribed song lyrics, and university ephemera, as well as materials documenting political activity on campus during the time period. Political materials include newspaper clippings, flyers, pins, and ephemera documenting on-campus issues such as the firing of John Hatchett, director of the Afro-American Student Center, as well as national and international issues, such as the Black Power movement and opposition to American involvement in the Vietnam War.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Nina B. de Fels Collection (dated 1967-1972) consists of materials created and collected by de Fels documenting her experiences as an undergraduate student at NYU's University Heights campus in the Bronx. The collection includes personal documents, including de Fels' transcript, acceptance letter, transcribed song lyrics, and university ephemera, as well as materials documenting political activity on campus during the time period. Political materials include newspaper clippings, flyers, pins, and ephemera documenting on-campus issues such as the firing of John Hatchett, director of the Afro-American Student Center, as well as national and international issues, such as the Black Power movement and opposition to American involvement in the Vietnam War.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged topically by the donor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Nina B. Fels were transferred to New York University in 2020 by the donor. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from repository. Please contact University Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Nina B. de Fels in February 2020; the accession number associated with this gift is 2020.018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Nina B. de Fels Collection; MC 350; box number; folder number or item identifier; New York University Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in an archival box and folders, maintaining the original topical groupings created by Nina B. de Fels. Materials were described on the collection-level with a folder inventory.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Nina B. de Fels (née Bauman) is a high school teacher in New York City. She attended New York University's University Heights campus as an undergraduate from 1968-1970.
